text: in the midst of the Great Depression a
12 year old boy named Boyd Lee Dunlop
came upon an old discarded piano the
wood was warped the keys damaged but in
its silence the piano all but dared the
boy to learn how to make it talk all the
men that got together through the peel
out of their yard into my house that's
just a look that said i'll be there now
i got it for you with that a lifelong
bond between man and instrument began he
studied a beginner's guide to playing
the piano he took five piano lessons
each costing fifty cents but stopped
when the teacher told him he was getting
ahead of the lesson plan no question
Boyd lead dunlap was good very good the
notes and chords the timing the rhythm
it all came naturally to him by the time
he was 15 he was playing religious
standards in church and swing standards
in a nightclub 70 years go by seventy
years of playing the piano in bars and
nightclubs living on the edge between
Fame and obscurity dealing with racism
trying to make a buck trying most of all
to make music suddenly Boyd Lee Dunlop
is living in a nursing home he is old
and little damaged and here in the
corner of the nursing homes cafeteria is
an upright piano also old and also a
little damaged it's missing keys it's
out of tune still he learns how to make
the good notes linger and the bad notes
die he makes it talk even sing someone
from the outside here's in play one
thing leads to another and now at 80
five years old Boyd Lee Dunlop pianist
will be releasing his debut CD called
Boyd's blues people who are said life is
what you make it never knock
you
